results.title: The Divine Garbo
results.creator_credit: Susan F Walker, Ellen Krass and Turner Pictures
results.brief_description: Garbo - the undefinable mystique. The most elusive, seductive and enigmatic actress the cinema has ever known, this Swedish star attracted audiences like no other. Her intense desire for privacy became legendary, vanishing from the screen - and the public - at the height of her commercial success. Hosted by actress Glenn Close, this video presents an insight to the mysterious Greta Garbo, including clips from such films as “Grand Hotel”, “Queen Christina”, “Anna Karenina”, “Camille” and “Ninotchka”, plus some rare behind-the-scenes glimpses, screen-test footage and foreign film clips - all of which only add to enhance the legend of one of Hollywood’s most elusive screen love goddesses.

results.title: The Discovery of insulin
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Here is the inspiring story of how, in July, 1921, in a little-used laboratory at the University of Toronto, two young Canadians, Frederick Banting and Charles Best, discovered insulin. Their work gave the hope of life and health to the world’s millions of diabetics. (An abridged version of The Quest)

results.title: 'Screen It' 2014 - Winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2014 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Reflection.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2014 Screen It competition!

results.title: The Diplomat
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Sally Browning, Wilson Da Silva, Emerald Films, Film Australia and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: For 24 years East Timor’s freedom fighter and Nobel Peace Prize winner Jose Ramos Horta campaigned to secure independence for his country, a former Portuguese colony invaded by Indonesia in 1975. This documentary follows him through the final year of East Timor’s struggle, a year that saw the fall of Indonesia’s President Suharto, the referendum to determine East Timor’s future, the overwhelming vote for independence, the devastating carnage that ensued, the subsequent intervention of United Nations peacekeepers, and Ramos Horta’s final triumphant return to his homeland. He emerges as a tenacious and beguiling character whose roles as a diplomat and peacemaker was a crucial one that helped finally deliver his country its freedom.

results.title: The Dingles
results.creator_credit: Les Drew, Bill Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Based on a story by Helen Levchuk, this animated short children’s film is the story of Doris Dingle and her three cat - Donna, Dayoh and Deedee - and their adventure one windy and rainy day. A funny and visually delightful for children aged three to ten and their parents. Illustrated by John Bianchi. (Awards: Chicago; San Francisco; New York) Also available on DVD [319319].

results.title: The Delian problem (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jean Nunn, Neil Cleminson, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Mathematics”.
Examines the problem of duplicating the cube, which amounts to finding the cubic root of 2 and is known as the Delian problem. Discusses the reformation of this problem in terms of finding two mean proportionals and the solution of the simpler problem of one mean proportional.

results.title: Numbers now and then (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jean Nunn, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Mathematics”.
Concerns the history of written numbers. Illustrates different features of the numeral systems of the ancient Babylonians, Egyptians and Greeks. Explains the Hindu-Arabic origin of our number system.

results.title: Quaternions: A herald of modern algebra (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Mathematics”.
A key mathematical development in modern algebraic ideas was the discovery of non-commutative algebras. William Rowan Hamilton worked on complex numbers and expressed them formally as pairs of real numbers. His work led him to try to generalise his ideas to three dimension but his generalisation to four dimensions led to the quaternion and the first non-commutative algebra.

results.title: The Diaries of Vaslav Nijinsky
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Aanya Whitehead, AFFC, Illumination Films (AU) and MusicArtsDance Films
results.brief_description: Poetic musing of a life drawn from diaries left by one of the world’s most famous ballet dancers. Vaslav Nijinski was a dynamic force in ballet, wanting to broaden the possibilities of dance - perhaps ahead of his time. Imagery from the natural world mixed with interpretations of ballets, historical documents and re-creations of the people and times of his life, are all lead by rich voice of Derek Jacobi, who narrates as Nijinsky reading directly from the dancer’s diaries. Thoughts on his career, his sexuality, his mental health and general place in the world reveal some of the inner turmoil of the man and his artistic temperament. His career was short lived as Nijinsky became mentally ill, remaining in an institution until his death in 1950. Directed and edited by Paul Cox “The Diaries” is a work that demonstrates the filmmaker’s passion for the dancer and writer that was Nijinsky. A co-production of Australia, Sweden, Germany and Netherlands. Original music by Paul Grabowsky. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Delia Silvan, Hans Sonneveld, Oliver Streeton, Jillian Smith.
